bioghist.p: The Academy of Natural Sciences of Philadelphia was founded in 1812 "for the encouragement and cultivation of the sciences, and the advancement of useful learning." Its collections, acquired through expeditions, gifts, purchases, and exchanges, contain over 17,000,000 specimens. The Academy opened its doors to the public in 1828, growing so rapidly that it outgrew its building three times in sixty years. In 1876, its present home was built at 19th and Benjamin Franklin Parkway. In 1948, with the establishment of the Environmental Research Division, the Academy broadened its research orientation to include applied research in aquatic ecosystems as well as the traditional systematics research--discovering and cataloguing organisms.

scopecontent.p: This collection consists of several accessions of materials from the President's office from 1874-2003, with the bulk of the material dating from 1930s to the 1990s. The records cover a wide range of topics, and include: correspondence; departmental reports; subject files; minutes of the board of trustees and its committees; minutes and notes from the Academy's participation in professional organizations and programs, such as The Associated Natural Science Institutions (TANSI) and the Wistar Institute; strategic planning, development, and marketing materials; documentation of exhibits; financial records; information on grants; personnel and hiring records; speeches of the president; and facilities and maintenance information. The collection also includes several cartons of data sheets from studies of the water and ecology of the Pawtuxent River (1960s and 1970s), as well as some photographs.
